Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Collaborative Research: Undersea Sensor Networks for Intrusion Detection: Foundations and Practice

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: Current technologies have made it possible for submarines to evade standard sonar detection. Finding solutions to detect intruding submarines therefore becomes important and timely. A viable approach is to deploy magnetic or acoustic sensors in close proximity of possible underwater pathways intruders may pass through. This project seeks to develop a comprehensive theoretical and practical solution to construct undersea sensor networks for intrusion detection. When sensors are randomly deployed, spatial barriers are unlikely to exist, allowing intruders to pass through the bounded 3D space undetected. This motivates the use of mobile sensors to dynamically form sensor barriers. How to minimize the energy consumed by the movement of underwater sensors is a challenging issue. This project tackles the problem via three thrusts: (1) Develop an energy-efficient approach to using mobile sensors to construct a spatial barrier in 3D space; (2) Devise near-optimal practical solutions to reduce computation and communication costs, and develop these algorithms into practical protocols; and (3) Develop simulation modules and test-beds to evaluate the proposed solutions with realistic undersea environment parameters. The project integrates concepts and techniques in auction algorithms, geometry, combinatorial optimization, underwater acoustic communications and networking, software and system development to construct analytical models and practical solutions. The research results are expected to have a substantial impact on the understanding of constructing sensing barriers in underwater environments, and will be integrated into graduate and undergraduate teaching and outreach activities. Efforts will be also proactively pursued to recruit students from under-represented groups to participate in the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Anti-submarine warfare (ASW) is facing a new challenge: Using new technology submarines can evade sonar detection. A viable alternative is to use magnetic or acoustic sensors in underwater pathways. For this purpose we studied how to deploy a large-scale underwater sensor network (UWSN) to form a 3D detection wall barrier using sensors with limited mobility. In particular, we focused on energy-efficient matching of mobile sensors to grid points using distributed auction algorithms. Through simulation we showed in comparison to the optimal solution, our approach offers reduced computation time and similar maximum travel distance. This result presents a way to construct a detection wall barrier in 3-dimensional sensor networks. Initially, sensors are placed in a deployment area, which may be drifted away by water currants, and we need to bring them back in and reform an UWSN barrier using the same algorithm.

We also investigated the practical impact of exiting MAC protocols for underwater acoustic networks (UWANs). In the underwater environment, radio signals suffer a heavy attenuation and cannot propagate far. Thus, acoustic communication becomes the viable solution. However, compared with the radio signals, acoustic signals propagate about five orders of magnitudes slower than the radio propagation speed, and thus introducing a long propagation delay. The bandwidth capacity of underwater acoustic channels is also very limited. We analyzed several real acoustic modems and studied the impact of these system features on the performance of existing MAC protocols with experiment and simulation results.
